question: Summarize the following evidence in 2-3 sentences.

content.source_1: I switched my 6-year-old collie mix with chronic IBS and a 3-year-old terrier to Wellness Simple Solutions because I was tired of boiling chicken and rice every night. I measured out 1 cup in the morning and 1.5 cups at night, added a splash of warm water, and kept a notebook on stool consistency. By day four the collie’s bathroom trips dropped from five to two, and the urgency episodes we track on his walks calmed down. The ingredient list is short enough that I can spot what’s in there without squinting. A 24-pound bag lasted just shy of a month for both dogs. Our vet liked that we weren’t hopping between proteins, and I’ve stuck with this while phasing in one new treat at a time without seeing the flare-ups that usually follow.
content.source_2: Focusing just on taste: my 9-year-old beagle sniffed the kibble, licked a couple pieces, and walked away. I tried softening it with warm water, mixed in a tablespoon of canned pumpkin, and even crumbled a little freeze-dried liver on top. He’d only eat it when I added sardines, and as soon as I stopped the toppers he refused again. Oddly, my neighbor’s lab finished a sample handful in seconds, so acceptance seems to vary by dog, but for mine the flavor or smell wasn’t enticing enough to get him to commit.
content.source_3: Zeroing in on quality and consistency: the first bag was fine in texture, but the second had a greasy film and a lot more crumbled bits—my measuring cup ended up half powder by the bottom third of the bag. The smell was also stronger in that batch, which my dog noticed; he hesitated and picked around the smaller fragments. The third bag arrived with a split seam near the zipper and I had to transfer it to a bin right away. The swings between bags make it harder to stick to a routine, and I’ve started checking lot numbers because the kibble density and oiliness don’t always match.
content.source_4: As an overall take, my 2-year-old pit mix reacted poorly after the switch: itchy ears, chewing at his paws, and watery stools within 48 hours. I did an elimination approach—stopped this food, gave him bland rice and turkey for three days, then tried a duck-and-potato formula and the irritation faded. I appreciate the limited ingredient approach in theory, but in practice something in this formula didn’t sit right with him. We ended up returning the bag and backing out of the transition plan entirely.
content.source_5: I’m focusing on the simplicity aspect. My 12-year-old Maltese has a history of food-triggered rumbling stomach and occasional bile vomits in the morning. With Simple Solutions, I could keep breakfast and dinner identical all week, then introduce one add-on at a time—first a teaspoon of canned pumpkin, next week a bit of boiled white fish—while tracking any changes. Not having peas, multiple proteins, or mystery “natural flavors” bundled together made it easy to pinpoint what caused a reaction. The routine became: 3/4 cup kibble, 50 ml warm water, sit for five minutes, and serve. When a test ingredient caused a hiccup, I pulled it and kept the base steady without having to change the main food.
content.source_6: Overall, this matched well with my 7-year-old German Shorthaired Pointer who’s insulin-dependent. We feed 1.5 cups twice daily, shots timed 15 minutes after meals. His glucose curve—checked with a Freestyle Libre sensor—smoothed out compared to the previous brand; fewer midday spikes, and the post-meal readings held steady enough that we didn’t adjust his 8-unit dose. He eats without coaxing and licks the bowl, and I sometimes blend in a quarter cup of Wellness Core to bump calories during hunting season. The resealable bag actually holds a seal, and the kibble shape works in a slow-feed bowl without jamming.
